properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A slow moving weather system approaching from the southwest will continue to bring periods of rain to the province, which are expected to persist today and overnight. A rainfall warning is in effect for the south shore of the province where total rainfall amounts between 40 to 70 mm are expected by tonight. The remainder of mainland Nova Scotia as well as Cape Breton could see between 25 and 50 mm of rain from this system before ending Wednesday morning. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2019-04-23T21:59:09-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-04-23T14:00:09-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2941282632.2019

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow, freezing rain, and ice pellets for tonight and Wednesday. A second shot of winter weather on Thursday and Friday. Significant snowfall is expected over northeastern Newfoundland tonight and Wednesday while significant freezing rain will affect the south coast and Avalon Peninsula. For further details on these areas, please refer to the Snowfall Warning and Freezing Rain Warning. For the remaining areas of the west coast, central and east coast, a mixture of ice pellets, snow and occasional freezing rain is expected. Although amounts may not be enough to require a warning, travel is still expected to be hazardous in these areas. Please consider postponing non-essential travel. With respect to the second system for Thursday and Friday: At this time the weather looks very similar to the first system. Significant snowfall is likely over parts of the island, with an area of ice pellets or freezing rain, as well as rain along the south coast. Further details will be provided on this next system in subsequent forecasts. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-04-23T21:26:31-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-04-23T13:27:31-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0805148596.2019
Area: Avalon Peninsula North, Avalon Peninsula Southeast, St. John's and vicinity, Avalon Peninsula Southwest, Burin Peninsula, Connaigre, Burgeo - Ramea, Channel-Port aux Basques and vicinity, Corner Brook and vicinity, Deer Lake - Humber Valley, Gros Morne, Bay St. George, Buchans and the interior, Grand Falls-Windsor and vicinity, Bay of Exploits, Bonavista North, Bonavista Peninsula, Clarenville and vicinity, Gander and vicinity, Green Bay - White Bay, Terra Nova

properties.Title: Update: Flood Warning Continues For The Red River From Emerson To The Red River Floodway Channel Inlet
properties.Summary:
Description: Update: This is a Manitoba Emergency Alert. Manitoba Infrastructure's Hydrologic Forecast Centre continues to issue a Flood Warning on the Red River from Emerson to the Red River Floodway channel inlet due to high water flows. If you are in the affected area, be watchful of local waterways as flooding is likely to occur. Do not attempt to cross fast flowing waters or waters of unknown depth. Avoid flooded areas. Follow all directions given by local authorities. Listen for updates and take all necessary precautions to stay safe. Up-to-date information is available at www.gov.mb.ca/flooding and www.manitoba511.ca or stay tuned to local media.
Expires: 2019-04-24T09:30:00-05:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Manitoba Emergency Measures Organization, 2019-04-23T09:43:18-05:00, C7B639DD-8506-8A23-4971-663CA08A4036
Area: Red River from Emerson to the Red River Floodway channel inlet
properties.Author: Manitoba Emergency Measures Organization

properties.Title: Wreckhouse Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Very strong wind gusts are expected or occurring Strong easterly winds will quickly increase in the Wreckhouse area this evening with gusts reaching 130 km/h. Winds are expected to diminish below warning criteria on Wednesday morning. ### Drivers may lose control of their vehicles; tall vehicles are at risk of being overturned. Wreckhouse wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with gusty winds and visibility frequently near zero in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. A deep Pacific low pressure system continues to move into southwest Yukon this evening. Consequently, periods of snow will become heavy at times and southwest winds will increase abruptly to 60 km/h gusting to 100 as the low moves inland. Snowfall accumulations of 10 to 20 cm are expected through tonight with frequent visibilities near zero in snow and blowing snow. ### Travel is expected to be extremely hazardous due to reduced visibility. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather in British Columbia or Yukon, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm or #YTStorm.
Expires: 2019-04-23T15:59:00-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-04-23T02:47:00-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2248080718.2019

properties.Title: Storm Surge Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: We expect higher than normal water levels near the coast this morning. Warning of potential coastal flood conditions issued jointly by Fisheries and Oceans Canada (Science) and the Meteorological Service of Canada for the Quebec region on 2019-04-23. A low pressure system is slowly moving up the Eastern US Seaboard and will bring moderate to strong winds to the regiom of the City of Quebec today. These winds, in combination with the high flows of the St. Lawrence River and the fact that we are currently in a period of high tidal range might give minor flooding along the coast near theses localities, at the dates and times specified (Eastern Daylight Time). City of Quebec: 2019-04-23, from 09:00 AM to 12:00 PM. ### Coastal erosion is possible in vulnerable areas. Storm surge warnings are issued when water levels pose a threat to coastal regions. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2019-04-23T17:59:25-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-04-23T08:41:25-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4122110063.2019
Area: Québec area, Côte-de-Beaupré - L'Île d'Orléans area, Bellechasse area, Lévis area
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 15 cm is expected. A pacific weather system is expected to bring significant snow to the Fort McPherson and Deline regions. Snow will begin later today, with 10 to 15 cm expected by Wednesday afternoon. However, there is expected to be a lull in the snowfall in the Deline region this evening, with the majority of the snow falling Wednesday. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NTStorm.

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Ice build-up due to freezing rain is expected or occurring. Freezing rain overnight tonight and Friday. Avalon Peninsula and Clarenville area: Scattered flurries are expected to develop overnight and change to freezing rain or ice pellets by early Wednesday morning. Freezing rain will transition to rain over the southern Avalon Peninsula by midday Wednesday and in the afternoon elsewhere. Precipitation will likely remain as freezing rain in the Clarenville area. South Coast: Precipitation is expected to begin as rain this evening and change to freezing rain overnight. Most areas along the coast will transition back to rain Wednesday morning or afternoon, while inland and higher elevation areas will see mainly freezing rain. Conditions will improve briefly Wednesday night before snow or ice pellets spread across the south coast on Thursday as another low pressure system approaches. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots will become icy, slippery and hazardous. Freezing rain warnings are issued when rain falling in sub-zero temperatures creates ice build-up and icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-04-23T22:26:39-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-04-23T13:27:39-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2638928102.2019
Area: Avalon Peninsula North, Avalon Peninsula Southeast, St. John's and vicinity, Avalon Peninsula Southwest, Burin Peninsula, Connaigre, Burgeo - Ramea, Clarenville and vicinity

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with gusty winds and visibility frequently near zero in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. A deep low pressure system continues to influence the Yukon today. A strong pressure gradient will cause very strong winds of 80 km/h gusting to 100 km/h near the Richardson Mountains. Combined with light snow, these winds will cause extensive blowing snow and reduce visibility to near zero. These blizzard conditions will persist through today and tonight. ### Travel is expected to be extremely hazardous due to reduced visibility. Road closures are possible. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather in British Columbia or Yukon, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm or #YTStorm.
Expires: 2019-04-24T03:59:50-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-04-23T12:00:50-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3991791907.2019
Area: Dempster

properties.Title: Update: Air Quality Due To Wildfire
properties.Summary:
Description: A wildfire is currently burning in the RM of Biggar, southwest of Biggar. Due to smoke and poor air quality R.M. of Biggar #347 and the Town of Biggar have declared a State of Emergency. Emergency services are requesting citizens avoid Hwy 51, Triumph Road and surrounding areas until further notice.

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, heavy at times is expected. The frozen ground has a reduced ability to absorb this rainfall. Additional rainfall amounts of 10 mm are possible today. This will bring total rainfall amounts up to 50 mm by this afternoon. The highest rainfall amounts are expected over southern portions of the region, including Timmins. The rain will change over to snow this afternoon. Lesser rainfall amounts are anticipated for northern sections of the region where more snow will fall. Over northern sections including Cochrane precipitation is expected to fall mainly as snow with local amounts possibly reaching 15 cm by this afternoon. For information concerning flooding, please consult your local Conservation Authority or Ontario Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry District office. ### Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
